contexts.title: The Superior Court of California - County of Ventura - FAQs
The Superior Court of California - County of Ventura - Small Claims
The Superior Court of California - County of Ventura - Small Claims
The Superior Court of California - County of Ventura - Small Claims
Small Claims | Superior Court of California | County of Tulare

agent_response: The venue for filing a small claims case depends on several factors, including where the defendant lives or does business, where the property was damaged or the injury occurred, where the contract was made or broken, and where the buyer or lessee signed the contract. If the defendant is a corporation, the claim can be filed where the contract was broken. If the claim is about a retail installment contract or a motor vehicle finance sale, the claim can be filed where the buyer lives, where the buyer lived when the contract was entered into, where the buyer signed the contract, or where the goods or vehicle are permanently kept. If your claim occurred in the east end of the county, your case will be set for hearing in the East County Division / Simi Valley location. If your claim occurred in any other zip code in the county, your case will be set for hearing at the Juvenile Justice Center / Oxnard location. However, all Small Claims filings must be filed with the Hall of Justice in Ventura regardless of your hearing location.

agent_response: Yes, a 17-year-old can be a defendant in a small claims case. However, the plaintiff must ask the court to appoint a guardian ad litem for the defendant if the defendant is not yet 18, as stated in the documents provided. A guardian ad litem is a person who will act for the defendant in the case and is usually a parent, relative, or an adult friend.

agent_response: According to the provided document, you can order a replacement New York boating safety certificate online at [https://www.ilostmycard.com/](https://www.ilostmycard.com/). However, if you are within 7 days of your temporary certificate’s expiration date and have not yet received your card, you should email [boating@parks.ny.gov](mailto:boating@parks.ny.gov). Please note that temporary certificates cannot be replaced.

agent_response: According to the provided document, anyone operating a Personal Watercraft (JetSki™, Wave Runner™, etc.) must have a boating safety certificate and be at least 14 years of age. Starting in 2024, if you are operating any other type of motorized boat, you will need a safety certificate if you were born on January 1, 1978 or later. Starting in 2025, all operators of motorized vessels, regardless of age, will be required to have a safety certificate. However, if you have a state safety certificate that was issued prior to 2000, it is only acceptable if you have a copy of it and you were under 18 years of age when it was issued. If you lost your certificate and it was issued prior to 2000, you may need to retake the course to obtain a new certificate.

rewritten_query: I need to know how to register my boat and boat trailer.

contexts.title: Renew Your Vehicle's Registration - California DMV
Motor Boating - NYSDEC
Renew Your Vehicle's Registration - California DMV
New York DMV | Vehicle Title
Motor Boating - NYSDEC

agent_response:
To register your boat in New York, you need to have it motorized (electric or fuel-driven), no matter how small the craft or the motor. You can register your boat online or by calling the DMV at (518) 486-9786. If your boat is not motorized, it does not need to be registered in New York.

For boat trailer registration, you can also use the same DMV online services or visit a local DMV office. You will need to provide the necessary documentation, which typically includes proof of ownership (title or registration), proof of identity, and payment for the required fees.

Please note that the registration process and requirements might vary based on your specific situation, so it's recommended to check the official New York State DMV website or contact them directly for the most accurate information.

However, if your certificate is from an online course, NYS can only issue replacement certificates for the NY Safe Boating Course.

agent_response: The New York State Adventure License program allows you to add your lifetime sporting and recreation privileges to your New York State driver's license. This includes privileges for hunting, fishing, and boating. The program is designed to make it easier for New York residents and visitors to participate in outdoor activities by keeping all their credentials in one place. To be eligible for the program, you must have a New York State driver's license and a qualifying lifetime sporting license or privilege. You can apply for the Adventure License at any DMV office. Please note that the Adventure License is not acceptable proof of a safe boating certificate outside of New York State.

2. Observe the navigational rules when operating your vessel.

7. Stay alert and watch for other boats, swimmers, and hazards.
8. Have a working marine radio on board to call for help in case of emergency.
9. Take a boating safety course to learn more about safe boating practices.

agent_response:
Based on the document from the Governor's Traffic Safety Committee, there are several regulations for motorcycle driving in New York. These include:

1. Always wear a DOT-approved helmet and eye protection when riding. "Novelty Helmets" are not approved and offer little protection to the rider in a crash.
2. Wear high-quality riding gear designed to protect the rider during a fall, including over-the-ankle boots, full finger gloves with padding, and jackets and pants with armor protection at impact points.
3. Maintain your motorcycle properly by ensuring all lights and horn are working, both mirrors are adjusted, tires are properly inflated, and have legal tread depth.
4. Maintain a high level of awareness and scan the roadway constantly for dangers.
5. Drive sober and never ride impaired by alcohol or drugs.
6. Be conspicuous by wearing high visibility vests, garments with reflector features, and accessories to boost your visibility to other drivers.
7. Observe and obey all traffic laws, signs, and signals.
8. Signal when you turn with your directional lights or hand signals, and flashing your brake light periodically before you stop will alert drivers behind you to be cautious.

Additionally, New York has a universal motorcycle helmet law that requires any person operating or riding a motorcycle to wear a DOT-approved helmet.

contexts.title: Office of Traffic Safety (OTS) Equity Statement  | Office of Traffic Safety
OTS Strategic Plan | Office of Traffic Safety
About OTS | Office of Traffic Safety
About OTS | Office of Traffic Safety
About OTS | Office of Traffic Safety

agent_response: The Office of Traffic Safety (OTS) is an organization that takes a leadership role in efforts to make California roadways safe for everyone using the transportation system. They strive to reach their goal of everyone traveling safely on California roads through grant funding made available to California by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). The OTS funds evidence-based education and enforcement programs and technologies designed to improve road safety, and evaluates all potential programs to make sure California addresses current and future traffic safety needs. They work with approximately 300 state and local agencies to make the most effective use of federal grant program funds, and coordinate with traffic safety partners to track successful programs, encourage collaboration, develop new countermeasures, and explore emerging trends. The OTS also shares the message of traffic safety through public awareness campaigns that educate the public on safe driving habits.

rewritten_query: What is the speed limit?

contexts.title: FAQs • San Bruno, CA • CivicEngage
FAQs • San Bruno, CA • CivicEngage
Frequently Asked Questions | California Air Resources Board
Safety Programs | Caltrans
OHMVR Frequently Asked Questions

agent_response: The maximum speed limit for any passenger vehicle in California is now 65 miles per hour (MPH). All other speed limits are called prima facie limits, which "on the face of it" are safe and prudent under normal conditions. Certain prima facie limits are established by law and include the 25 MPH limit in business and residential districts, the 15 MPH limit in alleys, at blind intersections and blind railroad crossings and a part-time 25 MPH limit in school zones when children are going to and from school. These speeds are not always posted but all California motorists are required to know these 10, 20, and 30 mile per hour speed laws. Intermediate speed limits between 25 and 55 miles per hour may be established by local authorities on the basis of traffic engineering surveys. These surveys include an analysis of roadway conditions, accident records, and the prevailing speed, or 85th percentile, of prudent drivers. If speed limit signs are posted for a lower limit than is considered reasonable, many drivers will simply ignore the signs. At the same time, other drivers will stay within the posted limits. This generally increases the conflicts between faster and slower drivers, reduces the gaps in traffic through which crossings could be made safely and increases the difficulty for pedestrians to judge the speed, of approaching vehicles. Studies have shown that where uniformity of speed is not maintained, accidents generally increase.

Violation | Base Fine | Penalty Assessment | Night Court fee | DMV Fee | 20% Criminal Surcharge | Court Security Fee | Total Fine Due

agent_response:
Based on the information provided in the documents, I can guide you through the general steps to file a restraining order in California. However, the exact process may vary depending on your specific situation and the court in which you are filing.

1. Determine the correct type of restraining order for your situation by referring to the "Types of restraining orders" document.
2. Obtain the necessary forms for your type of restraining order. You can find these forms on the California Courts website or at your local courthouse. Some common forms include the Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order (form DV-100), Temporary Restraining Order (form DV-110), and Notice of Court Hearing (form DV-109).
3. Carefully fill out the forms, providing detailed and accurate information about the situation and the orders you are seeking. Make sure to sign and date the forms.
4. Make two copies of the completed forms. Keep one copy for your records, and use the other copy to serve the other party.
5. Serve the other party with a copy of the forms according to the instructions provided by the court. This is usually done by someone over 18 who is not involved in the case.
6. After serving the other party, file the original forms and the Proof of Service (form DV-200) with the court clerk. There is no filing fee for restraining order forms.
7. Attend the court hearing scheduled on your Notice of Court Hearing form. Bring any necessary evidence and be prepared to explain your situation to the judge.

If you need help filing the restraining order, you can consult the Self-Help Center at your local courthouse or seek legal advice from an attorney.

agent_response:
In Sacramento, you can file a restraining order at the Gordon D. Schaber Sacramento County Courthouse. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Determine the correct type of restraining order for your situation by referring to the documents provided. For example, you can file a Domestic Violence Restraining Order, a Civil Harassment Restraining Order, or a Workplace Violence Restraining Order.
2. Obtain the necessary forms for your type of restraining order. You can download the forms from the Sacramento Superior Court website or pick them up in person at the courthouse.
3. Carefully fill out the forms, providing detailed and accurate information about the situation and the orders you are seeking. Make sure to sign and date the forms.
4. Make two copies of the completed forms. Keep one copy for your records, and use the other copy to serve the other party.
5. Serve the other party with a copy of the forms according to the instructions provided by the court. If the party you are serving lives or works in Sacramento County, the Sheriff's Civil Bureau can serve the documents to the other party. If the person to be served lives and works outside of Sacramento County, contact the Sheriff's Office of that county for help. Alternatively, someone you know can serve the restraining order documents to the respondent.
6. After serving the other party, file the original forms and the Proof of Service with the court clerk in the 1st Floor Lobby outside of Room 102 at the Gordon D. Schaber Sacramento County Courthouse. The court will process the forms, and the restraining order information will be entered into the Law Enforcement computer system and be accessible state-wide.
7. Attend the court hearing scheduled for your case. Bring any necessary evidence and be prepared to explain your situation to the judge.

If you need help filing the restraining order, you can consult the Self-Help Center at the Gordon D. Schaber Sacramento County Courthouse or seek legal advice from an attorney.

agent_response:
Based on the provided document, there are several types of restraining orders in California, depending on the situation:

1. Domestic Violence Restraining Order: This type is for protection from someone you have a close relationship with, such as a spouse, partner, or family member.
2. Civil Harassment Restraining Order: This order is for protection from neighbors, roommates, coworkers, or other people you don't have a close relationship with.
3. Workplace Violence Restraining Order: This order is for employers to protect an employee from violence or threats of violence at the workplace.
4. Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order: This order is for people aged 65 or older, or dependent adults who need protection from abuse, neglect, or financial exploitation.
5. Gun Violence Restraining Order: This order is for law enforcement or family members to prevent someone who poses a significant danger to themselves or others from possessing or purchasing a firearm.

Please refer to the "Types of restraining orders" document for more information about each type and to determine which one is best for your situation.

agent_response:
A civil harassment restraining order is designed to protect you from someone you are not closely related to or have not had an intimate relationship with, such as a neighbor, landlord, or coworker. To get a civil harassment restraining order, you will need to complete a few court forms, including one that asks you to describe in detail the harassment, stalking, threats, or harm you experienced. If you want help with these forms, you can contact your local Self-Help Center.

After filing the necessary forms, a judge will make a decision on whether to grant you temporary protection within a day or two. If the judge grants your request, they will issue a temporary restraining order, which will last until your court hearing. At the court hearing, the judge will decide whether to issue a permanent restraining order, which can last up to five years.

It is important to note that you cannot get a civil harassment restraining order against someone who is closely related to you, such as a spouse, parent, sibling, or child. In such cases, you would need to file for a different type of restraining order, such as a domestic violence restraining order.

A civil harassment restraining order is designed to protect you from someone you are not closely related to or have not had an intimate relationship with, such as a neighbor, landlord, or coworker.
Civil Harassment Restraining Order: This order is for protection from neighbors, roommates, coworkers, or other people you don't have a close relationship with.
Domestic Violence Restraining Order: This type is for protection from someone you have a close relationship with, such as a spouse, partner, or family member.

Attend the court hearing scheduled on your Notice of Court Hearing form.
If you need help filing the restraining order, you can consult the Self-Help Center at the Gordon D. Schaber Sacramento County Courthouse or seek legal advice from an attorney.
You can download the forms from the Sacramento Superior Court website or pick them up in person at the courthouse.
In Sacramento, you can file a restraining order at the Gordon D. Schaber Sacramento County Courthouse.
If the judge grants your request, they will issue a temporary restraining order, which will last until your court hearing.
After filing the necessary forms, a judge will make a decision on whether to grant you temporary protection within a day or two.
At the court hearing, the judge will decide whether to issue a permanent restraining order, which can last up to five years.
